text.p: UK airline Virgin Atlantic said on Wednesday it had launched a scheduled passenger service
between London Heathrow and Johannesburg's Jan Smuts airport.
In a statement Virgin said the route will be operated by the
airline's Airbus A340 aircraft, which offers an average cargo
capacity of 15 tonnes per flight as well as passenger space.
Initially the service will operate from Heathrow on Monday,
Wednesday and Friday. Due to re-allocation of take-off and
landing slots flights will be switched on October 27 to Tuesday,
Thursday and Sunday. The schedule is to be increased to six
flights per week in the spring of next year, when it will
operate every day of the week except Wednesday.
David Woodward, general manager commercial for Virgin
Atlantic cargo said: "South Africa is a very important and
rapidly growing market, and we have received considerable
interest from our customers since we first announced our
intention to service Johannesburg.
British exports to South Africa increased by 30 percent last
year to 1.8 billion stg with imports up 15 percent in 1995 to
1.1 billion stg.
Woodward added: "We foresee a considerable demand for cargo
space on this route. South Africa is the industrial and
commerical powerhouse of the continent, generating a huge and
varied spread of import and export traffic. We are targeting all
market sectors and are offering our full range of cargo
services."
